 Magnetic striping and polar reversals
 
 As more and more of the seafloor was mapped during the 1950s, the magnetic variations turned out not to be random or isolated occurrences, but instead revealed recognizable patterns. When these magnetic patterns were mapped over a wide region, the ocean floor showed a zebra-like pattern. Alternating stripes of magnetically different rock were laid out in rows on either side of the mid-ocean ridge: one stripe with normal polarity and the adjoining stripe with reversed polarity. The overall pattern, defined by these alternating bands of normally and reversely polarized rock, became known as magnetic striping.

 Mutation Rate Estimation. 
 
 The mtDNA tree of modern equids (zebras, asses, horses, hemiones) was compared with the osteological tree of modern and fossil equids, the latter tree being notoriously difficult to unravel (6, 18, 19). A phylogenetic network of the equid mtDNA control region sequences indicates that the mountain zebra split off first, then the asses, the Damara and Grant zebras, the Grevy zebras, the hemiones, and finally the horse (including the Przewalski's horse). The average branch length to the most recent equid mtDNA ancestor is 10.1 mutations in the 244 bp used for the horse phylogeny. The transition-transversion ratio in the equid network is not smaller than in the horse network, indicating that multiple hits at nps have been adequately resolved by the network algorithm. Our maximum fossil benchmark is the generally accepted date for the earliest known Equus fossil, Equus simplicidens, at ≈3.5 million y (20). Our minimum fossil benchmark for Equus is 1 million y, based on Eisenmann and Baylac's (6) latest date for the development of one cranial character common to all extant equid species, that is, their relatively long cranial length. This finding indicates a minimum mutation rate of 1 mutation per 100,000 y and a maximum rate of 1 mutation per 350,000 y, respectively.

 Ilya Prigogine, chemist-physicist, recipient of two Nobel Prizes in chemistry, wrote: "The statistical probability that organic structures and the most precisely harmonized reactions that typify living organisms would be generated by accident, is zero."(1) That's right - zero!
 

 
 Since someone else is dealing with the Francais Cricket quote, I will deal with the Ilya Prigogine quote. From Richard Carrier
 
 
 Ilya Prigogine
 
 Schroeder cites Ilya Prigogine as stating in Physics Today (in "Thermodynamics of Evolution," a two-part article spanning November and December of 1972) that "the idea of the spontaneous genesis of life in its present form is therefore improbable, even on the scale of billions of years." This is inherently suspicious, since Prigogine is famous for proving that order results from increasing entropy in dissipative systems, rendering spontaneous complexity more probable than ever before. So what is the context of this quote? As it happens, it appears in the introduction to that famous research article demonstrating that dissipative systems explain pre-biological evolution and in fact almost all order, even functional order, in organic systems, as a "purely deterministic" consequence of the laws of physics (ibid. Dec. p. 44). In other words, Schroeder is quoting a contrafactual and pretending it is a conclusion: the authors (Ilya is only the lead author of three, the others being Gregoire Nicolis and Agnes Babloyantz) first set out the challenging problem (the fact that the present theory does not account for biogenesis), which Schroeder quotes, then present the solution, which is mathematically and experimentally proven (and not only accounts for biogenesis, but also explains many other previously unexplained features of living organisms).
 
 Schroeder is thus guilty of deception, like those who quote Carl Sagan out of context (as I have discussed above). Ilya Prigogine and his colleagues actually prove, in that very article, that "the spontaneous genesis of life in its present form" is probable, not improbable. Indeed, their work demonstrates that given any "fluctuations" sufficiently far away from thermal equilibrium in a soup of polynucleotides (and perhaps also polypeptides), the development of complex reproducing systems is guaranteed, as a result of naturally-occurring "autocatalytic cycles" (ibid. Dec. p. 38), in just the same way that organized convection cycles arise naturally when water is heated (a state which is also very far from equilibrium). In a nutshell, the article comes to the exact opposite conclusion as Schroeder leads us to believe. So either Schroeder is trying to pull a fast one, or he did not read the article.

 I believe that there was a couple of cats at one time that were male and female with a 'fixed' gene pool.

 Some genes switch off - then - another turns on, which give's us the variation we see in the biology of earth.  Anyways, Certain variations were popular as they became more peculiar in their coloration and ability. As generations pass, soon there is no more connection to their great grand uncle and aunts, so the are now a new sub-species with less genetic coding than the first 2 cats. 
 
 The same is true of the Leopard. Narrower genetic code than the parents and 'different' genetic code than the mountain lion and the cheetah. 
 
 So rather than *re-engineering* the cats - we would be *restoring* enough of what was lost to expand the gene pool, b4 mutations eventually kill them all off.

 So evolutionists have departmentalized these processes with different scientific terms, but everyone knows that one process is just an extension of the other in fact.  Evolution and Abiogenesis
 v2.0 ©2006 Laurence A. Moran
 
 When we use the term "biological evolution" we have to have a consensus opinion on what this actually means. Is it some warm fuzzy notion about how change affects anything that has to do with life? If this is what we mean by biological evolution then it will probably include all of those changes that took place before free-living organisms arose. On the other hand, if we stick to a more scientific definition of evolution some biological changes won't be included. The question is whether the origin of life, or abiogenesis, is part of evolution or something separate.
 
 I think there's a scientific definition of biological evolution that has proved to be very useful in biology. It requires (by definition) populations of living organisms. Anything that preceded the formation of such populations is obviously relevant but it ain't biological evolution. Now, we could change the definition of biological evolution to include the formation of the first molecules that gave rise to living things but this would create more problems that it solves. We would still need a term for the evolution of populations by changes in the frequencies of their alleles.
 There's also a political consideration. Many people don't believe in biological evolution. I'd like to convince them that evolution, the process, is a fact. It's also a solid scientific fact that modern organisms evolved from a common ancestor that lived billions of years ago. These facts encompasses what I believe to be the core concepts of biological evolution. We have a chance to educate the public on this point. If people want to believe that the first living organism was created by God then I can live with that for the time being. First things first. Let's work on the evidence for biological evolution and not burden ourselves by linking it, incorrectly in my opinion, with the creation of life. That strategy is doomed from the beginning.
 
 I would say there's a form of "evolution" called chemical evolution. This contributed to the formation of the first living cells. There might well have been a form of selection among replicating molecules and there might well have been chance events that led accidentally to the enrichment of some other molecules. These two processes resemble natural selection and drift in the same way that those processes are echoed in genetic algorithms. However, it is useful to have a better working definition of natural selection (and drift) that applies to modern species. This definition requires populations of living organisms in order to have any usefulness. It isn't helpful to extend the definition of "natural selection" to the level of replicating molecules. If we do that we'll need a new term to represent the kind of mechanism that explains the evolution of the peppered moth and Galapagos finches. That new term will exclude selection of replicating molecules. The real question is whether the selection of replicating molecules and biological natural selection are the same phenomena. I don't think they are - this doesn't deny that there are similarities ... of course there are similarities.
 I would say that abiogenesis is not the same as biological evolution and it certainly isn't the same as "Darwinian evolution". I would argue that the origin of life was a spontaneous process that did not require anything out of the ordinary and certainly didn't require a supernatural being. However, I would also argue that biological evolution only began with the formation of the first population of living cells.

 The chance of getting a 6 once in a row is 1 in 6

 The point you are missing here is that if you take something that is very unlikely to happen (though still not infinitely improbable, as you would put it) if only attempted once, and you make a vey large number of attempts then it becomes very likely to happen.
 
 Let me give you an example.
 
 What are the chances of throwing a head (using a fair coin) 50 times in a row? Answer - around 1 chance in 1.126 x 10^15 (if attempted only once). You might describe this as astronomically small. But what if everyone on earth (or just 6 billion of them) tossed coins a million times each? What would be the chance that heads came up 50 times in a row for at least one of those people?
 
 Or what are the chances that heads came up 50 times in a row two, or even three times?
 
 This example is similar to your old argument about the probablility of a protein forming. Yes, the likelyhood of it happening is very very very small if only one attempt is made, but very very unlikely not to happen if given many billions of opportunities to happen.
 
 So, let go of your old feeble arguments about mathematical probabilities and learn something for once.

 Different Christian thinkers make different claims about the relation between body and soul when it comes to human beings. Aquinas, for example, thought the soul is unitary, but that it fulfills distinct vital, desiring, and rational functions. But he didn't make a distinction between soul and spirit, at least not in terms of human psychology. (So obviously, he was a pseudo-Christian, per Archangel's view of what true Christians think.) And that's just one example.
 
 The doctrine of the Trinity refers specifically to the idea of One God in Three Persons. The idea here is that God has a unitary nature, no matter how he is manifest: as Father, as Son, or as Holy Spirit. The problematic issues arise mainly from the status of Jesus. How, for example, can God be eternal, while Jesus clearly lived in time? Are we not thereby ascribing contradictory attributes to him? Prompted by such difficulties, some declared Jesus a perfect creation, rather than God himself. Controversy resulted in the Nicene Council of AD 325 making things official: Jesus was wholly divine, the same substance as the Father. The Doctrine of the Trinity, which had become largely accepted in an informal sense already, emerged from the council, with the Holy Spirit also officially acknowledged as the same as God. Controversies remained, however, insofar as Jesus is incarnate: God become human.

Actually, it's about God.
 
 Different Christian thinkers make different claims about the relation between body and soul when it comes to human beings. Aquinas, for example, thought the soul is unitary, but that it fulfills distinct vital, desiring, and rational functions. But he didn't make a distinction between soul and spirit, at least not in terms of human psychology. (So obviously, he was a pseudo-Christian, per Archangel's view of what true Christians think.) And that's just one example.
 
 The doctrine of the Trinity refers specifically to the idea of One God in Three Persons. The idea here is that God has a unitary nature, no matter how he is manifest: as Father, as Son, or as Holy Spirit. The problematic issues arise mainly from the status of Jesus. How, for example, can God be eternal, while Jesus clearly lived in time? Are we not thereby ascribing contradictory attributes to him? Prompted by such difficulties, some declared Jesus a perfect creation, rather than God himself. Controversy resulted in the Nicene Council of AD 325 making things official: Jesus was wholly divine, the same substance as the Father. The Doctrine of the Trinity, which had become largely accepted in an informal sense already, emerged from the council, with the Holy Spirit also officially acknowledged as the same as God. Controversies remained, however, insofar as Jesus is incarnate: God become human.
 
 
 
 No one has ever thought that the doctrine makes much sense in rational terms. Theologians generally declare it one of the mysteries of faith, a revealed rather than rational truth. For a rationalist like me, that's something of a problem. (But of course, I'm a very bad Christian.) It's hard to look at the history of the dispute and not see a human power struggle rather than a divinely granted insight.

 Well... Not exactly.
 
 Officially -- "officially" -- the Trinity is considered to be of significant importance. It amounts to an acknowledgement of the full divinity of Jesus and the Holy Spirit, without abandoning monotheism. The Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are not separate deities, but distinct Persons in the single Godhead.
 
 The problems come when you apply logic to the concept. The attempt to deduce the Trinity from God's nature doesn't work. And working out the implications quickly results in absurdities (God is one, yet not one, etc). Hence the Trinity's status as revealed rather than rational, a mystery to be accepted on faith not a conclusion to be reached by argument.
 
 The "angels-on-a-pinhead" is a criticism of the opposite theological tendency. It's a sarcastic quip not about how theologians declare anything significant yet problematic a mystery, but for how they apply precise logic even to questions of no significance at all.

 Nope. Let's look at the passage, as you've rendered it:
  Ephesians 4:4-6 There is one body and one Spirit-just as you were called to one hope when you were called- 5one Lord, one faith, one baptism; 6one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all.
 You have bolded certain portions that you seem to think make your case. But they don't, for several reasons. The first couple are semantic points, while the last is historical.
 
 1. The fact that the text uses "one" before each of the terms "Spirit," "Lord," and "God" implies the oneness of each of those things. But it need not indicate that the three together are to be understood as one thing. Indeed, you have boldfaced very selectively. What are we to understand about all the other terms the passage precedes by "one," and that are interspersed with the three spots you've boldfaced? I'm afraid I don't think the repeated use of "one" in this passage can do the interpretive work you need it to do.
 
 2. It is a major leap to consider "Lord" to mean the Person of the Son. The term "Lord" is certainly used with reference to Jesus. But "Lord" is also commonly used in reference to the Father. Why, then, should we presume it refers to the Son rather than the Father in this case? I don't think that's a justifiable move. So the upshot is, I'm not sure we should interpret this passage as even referring to all three Persons of the Trinity in the first place.
 
 3. The context in which Paul was writing has nothing to do with establishing the Trinity, as a theological, Christological, or metaphysical doctrine. The goal of Ephesians is much more mundane than that, though in some ways it might be (or might have been) much more important. The entire letter is a plea for unity in the Church, particularly given some raging controversies about whether Gentiles should be allowed to convert without first accepting Jewish law. (A lot of non-Jewish, adult males were less than enthusiastic about the circumcision requirement, for example.) Paul was always on the side of greater inclusion as an earthly realization of the universality of God's presence. Seen in the light of his unifying goals, the rhetorical emphasis on oneness is quite understandable. But it's not a oneness-of-three that is at issue.

 After all, my house is many bricks, yet it is one house. Indivisibly so - knock half of it down and it won't be a house anymore. And each brick is, unquestionably, made of the stuff of which a 'house' is made.

 Good question! And good points all. But the problem comes from the notion of God as not being composed of any parts in the first place: He is a single and simple thing outside of time, incapable of coming into or passing out of existence as are things that have parts (e.g. your house). What screws things up are the life of Jesus and the action of the Holy Spirit within time. It's not clear how these two can be said to be God without either denying God's own nature (as one, etc.) or ascribing contradictory attributes to him (eternal and temporal, etc.).
 
 Personally, I'm not at all sure that calling a truth "revealed" makes the problem inherent in this contradiction disappear. I'm not wild about the notion of a contradiction right at the heart of an ostensbly perfectly rational deity, who has reasons for everything He does.  I suspect that this aversion to multiple deities comes from comparisons to earlier pagan cultures that worshiped multiple deities where their lifestyles were viewed as corrupt and immoral. Also, many of the gods in polytheistic religions argued with each other, had intrigues, envies, etc. that disrupted human lives. However, I haven't heard too many arguements against polytheistic societies where the deities worked very well with each other (as, theoretically, one might say God the father, Jesus and the Holy Spirit do).
